Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: The effect of cognitive disturbance on functionally-relevant plastic behavioral responses
Award.AbstractNarration:
Ecosystems provide an invaluable suite of services to people, including cleaning air and water, cycling nutrients, preventing floods, and pollinating crops. A recent finding from the science of ecology is that more of these "ecosystem services" are provided in areas that contain many species of plants and animals than in areas that contain fewer; biodiversity has practical benefits. Studies of this relationship between species diversity and ecosystem services have focused on how physical differences between species are important in determining the services provided by a community (a group of species living in the same area). Recent studies, however, suggest that changes in animal behavior can also promote ecosystem services. Thus, it is important to understand how behaviors will be affected by environmental change, including chemical pollutants. This study will examine how pesticides affect bee behaviors important for plant pollination, including behaviors that depend on the number of species in a community. If pesticides disrupt the relationship between biodiversity and pollination services, they could have negative consequences for both native plant reproduction and the productivity of agricultural systems.

This study will examine the effect of sub-lethal neonicotinoid pesticide exposure on pollination-relevant bee foraging behaviors in both single and multiple species contexts. The behavior of pesticide-treated and control bees will be compared in laboratory experiments that use artificial flowers with computer-controlled nectar replenishment. Bee foraging behavior will be measured using RFID technology, which allows for exact tracking of bee movements. The researchers will measure pollination-relevant behaviors, including visitation rates, floral fidelity (temporary specialization on a particular flower type), and flower visitation evenness (the degree to which all flower species receive pollination services). It is hypothesized that pesticide exposure will affect bee species differently, altering competitive outcomes and modulating behaviorally-mediated biodiversity-ecosystem function relationships.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There has been increasing concern about declines in populations of pollinators, including bees. One of the drivers of bee declines is pesticide exposure, but we continue to know little about the negative effects of sublethal pesticide exposure (exposure at levels not sufficient to kill an individual pollinator) on bee health or on bees' ability to pollinate plants.

In addition, nearly all studies of sublethal pesticide exposure have focused on single bee species, while in most natural and agricultural settings, multiple pollinator species are present. Competition between pollinator species is thought to be an important factor shaping pollination interactions, and work has shown that having multiple pollinator species present can be beneficial for pollination outcomes. We hypothesized that interaction with other pollinator species may alter the effects of sublethal pesticide exposure, particularly if: 1) the presence of other species provides cognitive challenges; and 2) pesticide exposure affects cognitive function. We focused on the class of neonicotinoid insecticides, which affect neurotransmitters and which have previously been shown to have sublethal cognitive effects in bees.

To test this hypothesis, we examined the effects of sublethal exposure on bee foraging in experiments that also varied the number of bee species present (1-4 species) in a laboratory foraging enclosure with artificial flowers. We compared control bees (unexposed) to those exposed to a chronic dose of 10 ppb thiamethoxam (a field-realistic dose of a neonicotinoid pesticide) in maintenance nectar. We focused on foraging behaviors that are relevant for plant reproduction, including visit number; floral fidelity (tendency to forage on a single plant species, which is important for pollen transfer); and complementarity (tendency for different bee species to forage on different plants, which is important for ensuring that all plant species get pollinated).

 We found that bees exposed to a field-realistic dose of neonicotinoid pesticide gained less energy compared to control bees, while energy expenditures remained roughly constant. In addition, we found that in experiments with more bee species, the effects of pesticide exposure were exacerbated. In particular, flower visitation rates of exposed bees were greater than those of control bees in a single-species context (as expected for a pesticide with stimulant effects), but were significantly lower in experiments with multiple bee species. We are in the final stages of writing up these results for publication.

More broadly, this work shows that pesticide exposure can negatively affect bee energetics (with likely negative implications for bee populations) when multiple pollinator species are present. This work thus has important consequences for pollination and bee population dynamics in both natural and agricultural settings. In addition to improving our understanding of the consequences of pesticide exposure in pollinators, this project has also contributed to broader societal impacts by the training of one graduate student and an undergraduate student, the latter from a group under-represented in science. In addition, the experimental foraging enclosure we developed as part of this work has broad potential applicability for other studies related to animal foraging and behavior.
